Imagine owning a piece of your favorite travel destination that you could carry with you wherever you go. Something so unique and special that no one else can have it - an NFT (non-fungible token). That is exactly what Trip com's new product, Trekki NFT, promises to offer.
Trekki NFT is the latest addition to the world of Web3 and travel. It is an NFT marketplace that allows travelers to own a digital representation of their favorite travel destinations. These tokens can be used to enhance travel experiences, such as unlocking special discounts, access to exclusive events, and unique experiences.
By bridging travel and Web3, Trekki NFT has the potential to revolutionize the way we experience and interact with travel destinations. By creating a digital representation of a place, travelers can always carry a piece of it with them, even after they leave. It is a unique and innovative way to blend the physical world with the digital world.
Overall, Trekki NFT is an exciting new product that has the potential to change the way we think about travel and digital ownership. As the world becomes increasingly digital, having a tangible connection to the physical world becomes more important than ever.
Reference: https://www.phocuswire.com/trip-com-trekki-nft-travel-web3
https://akash.mittal.blog/web3/2023/6/5/Trip-com-unveils-Trekki-NFT-to-unite-travel-and-Web3.html
#trending #TripCom #TrekkiNFT #TravelWeb3 #DigitalOwnership

It was a beautiful Sunday morning. I was on my way to the nearby park for my regular jog when I saw a man with a large board that read, "AI will destroy humanity". He was surrounded by a group of curious onlookers, all wondering what he was talking about and why he was so passionate. As I walked closer, I overheard him talking about the dangers of AI and how it could bring the world to its knees.
While I could see his point of view, I couldn't help but wonder if he was missing the bigger picture. AI has the potential to revolutionize the world in ways we can't even imagine. It can help us solve some of the biggest challenges facing humanity today, from climate change to poverty and disease.
And that's exactly what Blackbaud, the world's leading cloud software company that helps organizations advance their social good efforts, had in mind when it unveiled its expansive vision to accelerate AI-fueled impact for purpose-driven organizations. The company believes that AI can be a force for good and has the power to transform the way we work, live and interact with one another.
AI is already making a difference in several sectors, and its applications are growing every day. Let's take a look at some of the most notable real-world examples of AI in action:
These are just a few examples of the many ways AI is making a positive impact in our world. Imagine what could be possible if purpose-driven organizations used AI to drive social good at scale!

Once upon a time, in the world of finance, there was a man named Warren Buffett. He was known for his ability to make wise investment decisions and generate substantial profits for his company, Berkshire Hathaway. However, Buffett saw an opportunity to make a profit by doing something that many investors would consider risky, he decided to short sell stocks.

For those unaware of what shorting a stock means, it is a way of betting against a company's stock. An investor borrows shares of a stock and then sells them for the current market value. The hope is that the stock will decrease in value so that the investor can buy back the stock at a lower price, return it to the original owner, and profit from the difference.
https://akash.mittal.blog/web3/2023/6/5/Warren-Buffett-and-His-Shorts-A-Story-of-Investing-Wisdom.html
#trending #WarrenBuffett #investingtechniques #shortselling #marketwisdom #smartinvesting #AIwrites #finance #investing

Web3, the next generation of the internet, is already here and it is rapidly evolving. From cryptocurrency to blockchain technology to decentralized applications, Web3 is creating a new digital landscape that is far more transparent, secure, and efficient than anything that has come before it. This article will explore some of the latest developments in Web3 and what they mean for the future of technology.
My interest in Web3 started a few years ago when a friend of mine told me about Bitcoin. At the time, I wasn't quite sure what it was or why it was important, but I decided to do some research. What I discovered was a technology that had the potential to transform the financial system as we knew it.
Since then, I have been following the developments in Web3 closely, and I have been amazed at the progress that has been made. What started as a niche interest has now become a global phenomenon, with millions of people around the world using cryptocurrencies and decentralized applications on a daily basis.
One of the most significant developments in Web3 over the past few years has been the rise of decentralized finance (DeFi). DeFi is a new financial system that operates entirely on blockchain technology, allowing users to borrow, lend, and trade cryptocurrencies without the need for traditional financial intermediaries.
The growth of DeFi has been phenomenal. In January 2020, the total value locked (TVL) in DeFi was just $675 million. By January 2021, it had grown to over $20 billion. And as of May 2021, the TVL in DeFi is over $80 billion. This represents a 12,000% increase in just 16 months.
https://akash.mittal.blog/web3/2023/6/5/Web3-Innovation-is-Far-From-Slowing-Down.html
#trending #Web3 #Blockchain #Cryptocurrency #DeFi #Decentralization

Artificial intelligence (AI) is revolutionizing the way we live and work. From Siri on Apple devices to self-driving cars, AI is making our lives easier, safer, and more efficient. But how does AI work? One important piece of the puzzle is the AI chip. In essence, AI chips are specialized processors designed to perform AI-specific tasks. So, what exactly are AI chips, and how do they work? Let's explore.
In 2016, Google's AlphaGo program defeated a world champion at the game of Go. This was a major milestone in the field of AI, as Go is an incredibly complex game with more possible moves than there are atoms in the universe. So, how did AlphaGo do it? One of the key factors was the use of specialized AI chips. Google's Tensor Processing Units (TPUs) allowed AlphaGo to perform calculations and make decisions at lightning-fast speeds, giving it a significant advantage over human opponents. This achievement was a clear demonstration of the power of AI chips and their importance in the field of AI.
At their core, AI chips are designed to handle the massive amounts of data required for AI applications. This includes processing data from sensors, making decisions based on that data, and learning from past experiences to improve future performance. Unlike traditional processors, AI chips are optimized for these specialized tasks, with features such as parallel processing, high memory bandwidth, and low-power consumption. This allows them to perform AI-specific tasks much more efficiently than traditional processors, which can be orders of magnitude slower and less power-efficient.
One company that has benefited from the use of AI chips is Sentient Technologies, a startup that uses AI to optimize e-commerce websites. According to the company, their AI system was able to significantly increase sales for several clients by optimizing product recommendations and search results using a combination of machine learning algorithms and AI chips called the Intel Xeon Phi. This is just one example of how AI chips are being used to solve real-world problems and improve business outcomes.
As the field of AI continues to evolve, AI chips are likely to become even more important and ubiquitous. Whether you're a scientist, engineer, or business owner, it's important to understand the basics of AI chips and how they can be used to solve real-world problems. With the right tools and knowledge, the possibilities are endless.
https://akash.mittal.blog/web3/2023/6/5/What-Are-AI-Chips.html
#trending #AIChips #ArtificialIntelligence #MachineLearning #TechNews

Have you ever wondered how chatbots are built? Nowadays, chatbots are everywhere and they are very useful in helping businesses engage with their customers. One of the most popular chatbot platforms is ChatGPT. It is a chatbot platform that uses artificial intelligence to communicate with users. However, building a chatbot takes more than just using the platform. Developers need an API key to get started. This article will explain what the ChatGPT API key is and where to find it.
The ChatGPT API key is a unique identifier that developers use to access the ChatGPT API. The API key allows developers to integrate the ChatGPT platform into their applications. Without the API key, developers cannot create, test, or deploy chatbots using the ChatGPT platform. It is a critical component for anyone who wants to build a chatbot using ChatGPT.
To find the ChatGPT API key, follow these steps:
Once you have the API key, you can start building your chatbot using the ChatGPT platform.
The ChatGPT API key is important because it is what allows developers to access the ChatGPT API. Without it, developers cannot create chatbots using the platform. In other words, the API key is the key that unlocks the ChatGPT platform's potential. It is a critical component for anyone who wants to build a chatbot using the ChatGPT platform.

It's 2 AM and the team at Nvidia is hard at work. They're not just building another supercomputer. They're building one that's so powerful, it's capable of solving problems that weren't even conceivable just a few years ago.
The team of engineers and scientists at Nvidia refer to this machine as an AI supercomputer, and with good reason. It's not just a quantum leap in processing power; it's a leap in artificial intelligence as well.
The core of Nvidia's AI supercomputer is its powerful chips. They're called Graphics Processing Units (GPUs), and they're designed to process huge amounts of data in parallel. This makes them ideal for machine learning, which requires massive amounts of data to identify patterns and make predictions.
The latest GPUs from Nvidia are capable of performing more than 100 teraflops, or 100 trillion calculations per second. That's more than 10 times faster than the fastest CPUs (Central Processing Units) available today.
One way to put this in perspective is to think about how long it would take a human to complete a simple addition problem like 2+2. We could do it in just a few seconds. But if we had to complete 100 trillion addition problems like that, it would take us more than 3 million years. That's just how much faster GPUs are than humans.
https://akash.mittal.blog/web3/2023/6/5/What-s-Inside-Nvidia-s-AI-Supercomputer.html
#trending #NvidiaAI #Supercomputer #AIbreakthrough

As artificial intelligence technology advances, so does the question of who is responsible for its creations. Is it the developers, the companies that deploy the technology, or something else entirely?
Imagine you are driving a car, and suddenly the car's autonomous system kicks in, taking control of the vehicle. As the car accelerates, it hits a pedestrian, causing serious injuries. Who is responsible for the accident: the car manufacturer, the software developer, or the driver?
This is not a hypothetical scenario â€" it's a real question that lawmakers and regulators are grappling with as autonomous vehicles become more common on our roads.
In this case, the liability would likely fall on a combination of the car manufacturer, software developer, and possibly the driver, depending on the circumstances of the accident.
Artificial intelligence is only as unbiased as the data it is fed. If an algorithm is trained on biased data, it can perpetuate and even amplify that bias.
https://akash.mittal.blog/web3/2023/6/5/Who-Is-Liable-for-A-I-Creations-The-New-York-Times.html
#trending #AIresponsibility #AICreations #TechnologyLiability #BiasinAI

Imagine this: you're having a problem with a product you purchased online, and you need help from customer service. You search the website for a way to contact them, but all you find is a chatbot.
You reluctantly type in your issue, but the bot's response doesn't address your problem. You try again, but the bot still can't understand. Finally, you give up and decide to call the company instead.
You're not alone. Many customers are finding that chatbots are more of a hindrance than a help. But what many people don't realize is that every time they use a chatbot, the company is losing money.
Chatbots may seem like a cost-effective solution for customer service, but the reality is that they can be quite expensive. For one thing, chatbots require constant monitoring and updating in order to function properly. This means that companies need to invest in personnel to manage them, which can add up quickly.
Furthermore, chatbots are not always able to solve customers' problems. When a customer gets frustrated with a chatbot and decides to call a real person instead, the company loses money. And even when a chatbot does manage to solve a problem, it takes longer than if a real person had handled the issue, which means that the company is still losing money.
https://akash.mittal.blog/web3/2023/6/5/Why-Chatbots-Lose-Money-Every-Time-You-Use-Them-A-Problem-That-s-Here-to-Stay.html
#trending #chatbots #AI #customerservice #technology #customerexperience #machinelearning #virtualassistant

It's no secret that Elon Musk is one of the most innovative thinkers of our time. His incredible work with SpaceX, Tesla, and The Boring Company have all been game-changing in their respective industries. But there are a couple of things he's now regretting, namely letting go of two promising ventures, ChatGPT and OpenAI, which could have been even more significant contributors to the world.
It all started back in 2015, when Musk and a group of tech entrepreneurs founded OpenAI. The non-profit AI research organization had lofty goals of helping ensure that AI is beneficial to humanity. And for the first few years, things were going incredibly well. They were making significant breakthroughs, attracting top talent, and collaborating with some of the most respected institutions in the field.
Similarly, Musk himself invested a lot of money into a startup called Vicarious, which was developing advanced algorithms for unsupervised learning. The idea was that this technology could help them create intelligent software that could learn and adapt on its own, much like a human brain. However, as time passed, Musk began to realize that there were limitations to what he could accomplish alone, even with his considerable resources. That's when he decided to let ChatGPT and OpenAI loose up to create their own AI.
Unfortunately, this ended up having less than desirable outcomes. Though Musk's intentions may have been pure, the truth is that he ended up creating serious competition for himself. ChatGPT, which was spun out of OpenAI and specialized in natural language processing, quickly became one of the hottest AI startups around. And as it turned out, they were churning out some of the most impressive AI language models.
This experience led Musk to empathize with others who may have faced similar disappointment when relinquishing control of a promising venture. At the same time, he realized that he should have spent more time considering the long-term implications of his actions. These experiences motivated him to talk openly about the importance of innovation and its potential impact on humanity.
https://akash.mittal.blog/web3/2023/6/5/Why-Elon-Musk-Regrets-Letting-ChatGPT-and-OpenAI-Go.html
#trending #elonmusk #OpenAI #ChatGPT #AIinnovation #entrepreneurship

Many people believe that we are witnessing another dotcom bubble, but this time in the field of artificial intelligence (AI). The concerns are understandable, given the hype and investment surrounding the technology. However, AI is not a repetition of the dotcom era, and in this article, we will explore why that is.
We will share some quantifiable examples of how AI is transforming industries and tackle the reasons why AI is different from the dotcom boom. Additionally, we will touch on some exciting case studies that illustrate our points. Finally, we will provide some practical tips for businesses so that they can best prepare for the AI revolution.
Investors were so enthusiastic about dotcom businesses, they were willing to back the ideas of anyone who could put together a website. Millions of dollars chased businesses whose revenues were paltry, at best. When investors began to realise that these businesses could not deliver the revenue growth to justify their valuations, the bubble burst.
AI has already contributed to significant progress in various sectors.
Unlike the dotcom era, where many people invested vast amounts of money in the hope of becoming millionaires overnight, AI investment is more measured.
https://akash.mittal.blog/web3/2023/6/5/Why-the-AI-Boom-is-Not-a-Dotcom-Redux.html
#trending #examples #conclusion #end #ArtificialIntelligence #DigitalTransformation

Have you ever come across an LLM (Language Learning Model) that imitates ChatGPT TechTalks? It may seem like a good idea to use a popular platform to learn a new language, but there are certain risks associated with it. Let me tell you a story that illustrates this point.
One day, John, an English speaker, decided to learn Chinese with an LLM that imitates ChatGPT TechTalks. He found a conversation on the platform where two Chinese native speakers were discussing the weather. He thought it would be a good idea to practice his Chinese by joining the conversation.
He typed in the chat, "ä½ ä»¬è§‰å¾—ä»Šå¤©å¤©æ°"æ€Žä¹ˆæ ·ï¼Ÿ" (What do you think about the weather today?), but to his surprise, the two native speakers didn't respond. John thought his Chinese was not good enough, so he tried again, but still no response. He felt discouraged and confused.
What John didn't realize was that the LLM had a delay in response time and the native speakers had already left the conversation. He also didn't know that the conversation was moderated by the LLM and his message was not sent to the actual native speakers. He was simply talking to a machine, not a human.
This story illustrates the danger of using LLMs that imitate ChatGPT TechTalks. Not only do they create a false sense of interaction, but they also prevent learners from practicing with real native speakers.
https://akash.mittal.blog/web3/2023/6/5/Why-You-Should-Be-Careful-About-LLMs-That-Imitate-ChatGPT-TechTalks.html
#trending #LanguageLearning #NativeSpeakers #LLMs

However, when he logged into his Zoom account, he was amazed to find that the software had generated an AI summary of the meeting for him. Within minutes, he was able to catch up on everything that had happened, just as if he had attended the meeting.
From that day on, John was a firm believer in the power of Zoom AI summaries.
